person_096.name: Giovanni RaimondoTorlonia
person_096.description: A famous Franco-Italian banker to the Vatican and noble of the Torlonia family.

person_095.name: AndrewDrummond
person_095.description: Scottish founder of Drummond's Bank, Charing Cross, in 1717. Davy banked there and with its successor, Drummond and Morland and Company.

person_098.name: JosephineDetela
person_098.description: The daughter of the landlord of the Laybach (Ljubljana) inn at which Davy stayed in 1827 and 1828. Davy nicknamed her 'Pepina'. In Consolations in Travel (1830) he portrayed her in idealised terms as his nurturing nurse.

person_101.name: Ambrosio
person_101.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_031.name: JohnMilton
person_031.description: Milton was a poet and polemicist. He wrote the epic poem Paradise Lost.

person_102.name: Philalethes
person_102.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_151.name: Edward CharlesHoward
person_151.description: A brother of the Duke of Norfolk, he became a chemist, discovering the explosive properties of mercury fulminate. FRSL

person_108.name: Onuphrio
person_108.description: Onuphiro is the name of a fictional character in the dialogues of Davy's Consolations in Travel. The anglicized version of the name is Humphry.

person_107.name: AlexanderHohenlohe
person_107.description: A Hohenlohe prince ordained (1815) a Roman Catholic priest, he claimed to have performed many miraclous cures.

person_109.name: Jagannath
person_109.description: A supreme diety worshipped in Hindu traditions.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_114.name: Muhammad
person_114.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

person_115.name: Moses
person_115.description: According to the Old Testament Hebrew prophet who is considered the most important prophet in Judaism and one of the most important prophets in Christianity and other religions.

person_119.name: NapoleonBuonaparte
person_119.description: French general and, as First Consul, 1799-1804, and Emperor, 1804-1815, military dictator of France and the territories it occupied. Established the Volta prize for research electricity and provided Davy with a passport to collect it in Paris in 1813.

person_118.name: George GordonByron
person_118.description: From 1798 6th Lord Byron. Famous poet who knew both Humphry and Jane Davy in London and Italy; he wrote a slightly risqué skit on their marriage in 1812. FRSL.

person_121.name: JohnFreeborn
person_121.description: Banker, merchant and British cousul in Rome.

person_120.name: JohnDavy
person_120.description: Humphry Davy's brother, born in Penzance. Spent some time working with Davy in the Royal Institution before studying medicine at Edinburgh University. Appointed an Army physician he was elevated to the rank of Inspector General of Army Hospitals in the West Indies. Following his brother's death, Davy's notebooks came into his possession which he used in writing biographical studies that strongly defended his reputation. FRSL.

person_122.name: The Unknown
person_122.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_123.name: Barnaba Niccolò Maria LuigiChiaramonti
person_123.description: Pope Pius VII, 1800-1823, held prisioner by Buonparte, 1809-1813. In February 1814 Davy and his party stayed in the same inn that Pius had used the week before on his way back to Rome.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_125.name: JamesHutton
person_125.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

person_070.name: JaneDavy
person_070.description: Daughter of Charles Kerr, an Antiguan merchant who made his fortune in highly dubious circumstances. Following his death she moved to Britain where she married Schukbrugh Apreece who died in 1807. After running a successful literary salon in Edinburgh she moved to London where she met Davy and they married on 11 April 1812 two days after he had been knighted by the Prince Regent.

person_127.name: JohnMurray
person_127.description: Publisher of many of the key literary and scientific texts of the time, including by Byron, Austen, Davy. Published The Quarterly Journal of Science (closely likned to the Royal Institution) as well as Davy's Six Discourses (1827), Salmonia (1828) and Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_105.name: ThomasPoole
person_105.description: Tanner based in Nether Stowey, philanthropist and essayist; a friend of Davy and Coleridge.

person_130.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
person_130.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

person_066.name: JohnDalton
person_066.description: Mancunian chemist and natural philosopher who lectured at the Royal Institution. He formulated a version of the atomic theory of matter much disliked by Davy. FRSL.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_1103.name: Maria Anna ElisaBonaparte Baciocchi Levoy
person_1103.description: An imperial French princess and sister of Napoleon Bonaparte. She was Princess of Lucca and Piombino (1805-1814), Grand Duchess of Tuscany (1809-1814) and Countess of Compignano by appointment of her brother. Highly interested in the arts, particularly the theatre, she encouraged them in the territories over which she ruled. An 1812 painting by Benvenuti shows her presiding over artists at her court in Florence.

person_141.name: Jean-AntoineChaptal
person_141.description: French chemist, physician and industrialist. ForMemRSL.

person_142.name: CharlesBlagden
person_142.description: Physician who kept a revealing diary for most of his life. A friend of Joseph Banks serving as a Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1784-1797; Knighted 1792. FRSL

person_143.name: BenjaminThompson
person_143.description: Born in Massachusetts, he served in the British and Bavarian armies. Knighted by George III in 1787, the Elector of Bavaria created him Reichsgraf von Rumford of the Holy Roman Empire in 1792. His appointment in the late 1790s as Bavarian ambassador to London created a minor diplomatic incident, during which he helped establish and manage the Royal Institution, in the course of which he appointed Davy to lecture there. Later he married Lavoisier's widow and lived unhappily ever after. FRSL.

person_144.name: JosephBanks
person_144.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

person_664.name: NevilMaskelyne
person_664.description: Astronomer Royal and a Commissioner of the Board of Longitude. Contributed to scientifically measuring the density of the Earth. FRSL.

person_029.name: ThomasBeddoes
person_029.description: A politically radical (Jacobin) chemist and physician who in the 1790s established the Medical Pneumatic Institution in Bristol to investigate the physiological and possible curative effects of all the gases discovered during the eighteenth century. Between late 1798 and early 1801 he employed Davy as Superintendent of the Institution.

person_146.name: JamesWatt
person_146.description: A Scottish scientific instrument maker who studied with the chemist Joseph Black at Glasgow University. He developed the separate condenser for steam engines which increased their effieciency significantly. He took out a twenty-five-year patent (ending in 1800) and moved to Birmingham where he went into partnership with the businessman and industrialist Matthew Boulton. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines. A friend of Thomas Beddoes, he met Davy on a number of occasions and Davy gave the oration at the unveiling of Watt's statue in Greenock. FRSL.

person_147.name: MattthewBoulton
person_147.description: Birmingham businessman and industrialist who went into partnership with James Watt to manufacture efficient steam engines using Watt's patent for the separate condenser. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines until the patent expired in 1800. An early Proprietor of the Royal Institution, he had grave doubts about Rumford's proposal to freely display inventions there. FRSL.

person_372.name: FrancisHome
person_372.description: Physician and Professor of Materia Medica at the University of Edinburgh, 1768-1798.

person_149.name: CharlesHatchett
person_149.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

person_068.name: SmithsonTennant
person_068.description: Tennant was a botanist and chemist and knew Davy through agricultural improvements. Appointed Professor of Chemistry at Cambridge University in 1813, he was killed in a riding accident on France. FRSL.

person_150.name: William HydeWollaston
person_150.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

person_152.name: Michel EugèneChevreul
person_152.description: French organic chemist. Met Davy when he was in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_023.name: RichardKirwan
person_023.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

person_050.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
person_050.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_153.name: Pierre LouisDulong
person_153.description: French physicist and chemist who worked mostly on specific heats, but also discovered nitrogen chloride around the same time as Davy. ForMemRSL.

person_003.name: WilliamAllen
person_003.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

person_015.name: William HaseldinePepys
person_015.description: Pepys was a surgical and scientific instrument maker and chemist. Constructed large batteries used by Davy (amongst others). FRSL.

person_154.name: DaviesGiddy
person_154.description: Changed his surname to Gilbert in 1817. A member of the West Cornwall gentry, he was one of Davy's earliest patrons. A former student of Beddoes at Oxford University, he was a key figure in securing Davy's appointment in 1798 to the Medical Pneumatic Institution. He maintained contact with Davy throughout his life and following his death suceeded Davy as President of the Royal Society of London. FRSL.

person_049.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
person_049.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

person_157.name: André-MarieAmpère
person_157.description: French physicist and mathematician and one of the key figure in the early study of electro-magnetism. Davy met him in Paris in 1813 and they developed a scientific rivalry. ForMemRSL.

person_158.name: TeodoroMonticelli
person_158.description: Neapolitan naturalist with an interest in volcanology and the mineralogy of Vesuvius. One of Davy's closest contacts in Naples.

person_159.name: GeorgesCuvier
person_159.description: French naturalist and zoologist who was one of the founders of palaeontology. Perpetual Secretary of the first class of the Institut de France (Académie des Sciences), Davy met him when in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_160.name: WilliamBuckland
person_160.description: Anglican priest who was later Dean of Westminster. Perhaps the last serious geologist to attempt the reconciliation of the findings of contemporary geology with the Biblical accounts. FRSL.

person_161.name: GeorgeKnox
person_161.description: Irish politician who sat in the Dublin and then Westminster parliaments. A collector of minerals, it is not known how he came to know Davy. FRSL.

person_162.name: JohnPlayfair
person_162.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

person_163.name: Thomas CharlesHope
person_163.description: Professor of Medicine and Chemistry at Edinburgh University. Discovered the element strontium and seems to have played a role in Davy's appointment to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_164.name: JamesHall
person_164.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

person_165.name: WilliamHiggins
person_165.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

person_167.name: HeinrichOlbers
person_167.description: Astronomer who worked in Bremen. He specialised in the detection of asteroids and propounded his eponymous paradox. Davy met him on a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

person_168.name: Carl FriedrichGauss
person_168.description: Prominent Hanoverian mathematician who was Director of the observatory at Gottingen University. Davy met him during a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

person_169.name: Heinrich ChristianSchumacher
person_169.description: Founder and Directort of the Altona astronomical observatory. Davy met him during a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

person_170.name: George IV
person_170.description: Eldest son of George III and Prince of Wales. Served as Prince Regent during the King's madness, 1811-1820, thereafter King of England, Scotland and Ireland. A major patron of the arts, he personally commanded Davy to go to Naples to oversee the unrolling of the Herculaneum papyri. PatronRSL.

person_171.name: Caroline
person_171.description: Of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel who in 1795 married the Prince of Wales (later Prince Regent and George IV. They soon separated causing a series of scandals that lasted until her death. The Davys tended to take her side.

person_172.name: AntonioCanova
person_172.description: Italian sculptor and friend of the Davys.

person_173.name: Samuel TaylorColeridge
person_173.description: Poet and philosopher who met Davy while in Bristol with whom he became a close friend. Suggested that if Davy had not been the first chemist of the age, would have been the first poet.

person_174.name: WalterScott
person_174.description: Scottish poet and novelist. Knew Davy from  1805 when with Wordsworth they together climbed Hellvellyn. Scott was also a distanct cousin of Lady Davy, whom he could not stand.

person_186.name: RobertSouthey
person_186.description: Poet who met Davy in Bristol and included some of his poems in Annual Anthology. Poet Laureate from 1813 until death.

person_187.name: ThomasLawrence
person_187.description: Prominent portrait painter and President of the Royal Academy, 1820-1830. Painted the famous portrait of Davy as President of the Royal Society of London. FRSL.

person_188.name: Francis LeggattChantrey
person_188.description: Prominent English sculptor who, at the request of Lady Davy, made the memorial plaque to Davy placed in Westminster Abbey. FRSL.

person_189.name: WilliamWordsworth
person_189.description: English poet who, with Samuel Taylor Coleridge, published Lyrical Ballads. Davy contributed to seeing the second edition (1800) through the press in Bristol. Poet Laureate from 1843.

person_183.name: NickolasEsterhazy
person_183.description: Hungarian prince and patron of the arts, especially music. Davy presented him with a copy of Salmonia.

person_138.name: Aristotle
person_138.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

person_185.name: Pliny
person_185.description: The Elder. Roman army officer and author who wrote an encyclopedic Natural History. Died in the aftermath of the eruption of Vesuvius.

person_191.name: John JamesTobin
person_191.description: Son of Davy's old friend James Webbe Tobin, he trained as a physician before accompanying Davy in 1828 and 1829 as his companion, secretary, and amanuensis during his tour of Italy and the Alps. Davy's name for Tobin was Wildeman or 'wild man'.

person_166.name: BryanHiggins
person_166.description: Irish chemist and natural philosopher who developed a form of the atomic theory of matter. Worked in London, St Petersburg and Jamacia. Uncle of William Higgins.

person_175.name: Miltiades
person_175.description: Greek Athenian citizen known mostly for his role in the Battle of Marathon.

person_210.name: WilliamBabington
person_210.description: Physician to Guy's Hospital and mineralogist, one of the founders of the Geological Society. A close friend of Davy, Babington was one of those who treated him during his severe illness of late 1807, early 1808. Shared his enthusiasm for angling. FRSL.

person_194.name: EdwardJenner
person_194.description: Lived in Berkeley, Gloucestershire, where he pioneered vacination, especially for smallpox. FRSL.

person_195.name: MatthewBaillie
person_195.description: Physician and brother of Joanna Baillie. One of the doctors who saw Davy during his serious illness from late 1807 to early 1808. FRSL.

person_196.name: Alexander John GaspardMarcet
person_196.description: Genevean-born physician who settled in London and lectured on chemistry at Guy's Hospital. A friend of Davy's. FRSL.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_193.name: JamesWoodhouse
person_193.description: Physician and professor of chemistry at University of Pennslyvania from 1795. Visited London in 1802 where he met Davy and later repeated his experiments on nitrous oxide.

person_197.name: CorneliusCardew
person_197.description: Headmaster of Truro Grammar School where Davy was a pupil during 1793.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_199.name: AlessandroVolta
person_199.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

person_198.name: GuiseppePiazzi
person_198.description: Professor of astronomy at the University of Palermo. Discovered the first asteroid, which he named Ceres, in 1801. ForMemRSL

person_200.name: Domenico LinoMorichini
person_200.description: Italian physican and chemist. Professor of Chemistry at the Univerity of Rome from 1798 to his death. Gave Davy medical advice in his final years. ForMemRSL.

person_012.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
person_012.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

person_201.name: Louis JacquesThénard
person_201.description: Held chairs of chemistry at the Collège de France and the Ecole Polytechnique. Worked closely with Gay-Lussac and met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_202.name: Dominique François JeanArago
person_202.description: French mathematician, physicist, astronomer and political liberal. Davy presented him with the Copley Medal in 1825. ForMemRSL.

person_203.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
person_203.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

person_205.name: Daniel CarlssonSolander
person_205.description: Swedish-born naturalist who worked at the British Museum cataloguing their natural history collections according to the Linnean system. Close to Banks, he accompanied him on various vayages including the Endeavour expedition to the Pacific. FRSL.

person_206.name: WilliamHenry
person_206.description: Manchester physician and chemist, whose Elements of Experimental Chemistry went through eleven editions. FRSL.

person_207.name: William ThomasBrande
person_207.description: Originally trained as an apothecary, Brande became a chemist. With Davy and others founded the Animal Chemistry Club. Lectured on chemistry in various London institutions and, following Davy's retirement succeeded him in his positions at the Royal Institution where he founded The Quarterly Journal of Science. A Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1816-1826; later fell out with Davy. FRSL.

person_209.name: ThomasYoung
person_209.description: Linguist, physician, mathematician and natural philosopher amongst other activities. Professor of Natural Philosophy at the Royal Institution, 1801-1803, but was not a good lecturer. Later worked on deciphering the Rosetta stone. Served as Secretary to the Board of Longitude and Foreign Secretary of the Royal Society of London. FRSL.

person_772.name: David BailieWarden
person_772.description: Republican insurgent in the Irish Rebellion of 1798 and, in later exile, a United States consul in Paris.

person_217.name: Halieus
person_217.description: A fictional character in Davy's Salmonia: Or, Days of Fly-fishing (1828).

person_220.name: IzaacWalton
person_220.description: Author of The Compleat Angler (1653 and many later editions), the foundational English text for writing about fishing. Davy owned several copies.

person_233.name: JohnChurchill
person_233.description: Senior army commander and politician under Queen Anne. Created 1st Duke of Marlborough in 1702, he commanded the army at the Battle of Blenheim (1704). For that victory Parliament voted funds to build Blenheim Palace.

person_234.name: FilippoCaviolini
person_234.description: Professor of Zoology at the University of Naples; specialised in marine life.

person_235.name: Marcus ElieserBloch
person_235.description: German physician and naturalist who specialised in the study of fish on which he published a 12 volume work with which Davy was familiar. (presumably in the French translation).

person_259.name: Charles-FrédéricReinhard
person_259.description: French diplomat who served under a number of regimes.

person_530.name: PulteneyMalcolm
person_530.description: Royal Navy naval officer rising to the rank of Admiral. He oversaw the imprisonment of Napolean on St Helena.

person_078.name: JohnLocke
person_078.description: English philosopher and physician, widely regarded as one of the most influential of early Enlightenment thinkers. FRSL.

place_154.name: St. Peter's
place_154.description: St Peter's is a church built in the Renaissance style located in the Vatican City, west of the River Tiber.

place_153.name: The Albergo Serny
place_153.description: A hotel popular with English travellers in Rome, near the Piazza di Spagna.

place_156.name: Naples
place_156.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

place_157.name: Malafede
place_157.description: Decima Malafede is a nature reserve within the district of Rome.

place_1393.name: Saline di Ostia
place_1393.description: Saltwater ponds in Ostia, Rome which were drained in the early twentieth century.

place_171.name: San Gimignano
place_171.description: Porta San Giovanni is a gate in the Aurelian Wall of Rome, Italy.

place_174.name: Pantano Borghese
place_174.description: On the outskirts of Rome south of Tivoli, an estate that since 1613 has belonged to the Borghese family.

place_175.name: Vauxhall Gardens
place_175.description: A pleasure garden in London in the late eighteenth and nineteenth century. Davy wrote a poem titled 'Vauxhall'.

place_529.name: Tivoli, Lazio
place_529.description: Tivoli is a town north east of Rome and known for the waterfall on the Aniene River.

place_940.name: Orkney
place_940.description: An archipelago off the northeastern coast of Scotland.

place_222.name: Africa
place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

place_179.name: Albulae Aquae
place_179.description: White Waters'; a group of springs to the west of Tivolo, Italy, and location of an ancient Roman settlement.

place_180.name: Paestum
place_180.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

place_181.name: Carniola
place_181.description: The Alpine region whose capital was Laybach (now Ljubljana). In 1827, Carniola was a Duchy within the Austrian Kingdom of Illyria.

place_182.name: Traun
place_182.description: Traunfall in Desselbrunn, Upper Austria. Memoirs contains a poem Davy wrote about them, also in notebook 14E.

place_184.name: Mount Etna
place_184.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

place_192.name: Illyrian Alps
place_192.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

place_247.name: Alps
place_247.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

place_328.name: Tyrol
place_328.description: Tyrol is a historical region in the Alps located in northern Italy and western Austria.

place_193.name: Noric Alps
place_193.description: The Noric Alps is a collective term for a group of mountain ranges in the Eastern Alps.

place_194.name: Julian Alps
place_194.description: The Julian Alps are a mountain range in the Southern Limestone Alps, Slovenia. Mount Triglav is the highest point.

place_329.name: Carinthia
place_329.description: Carinthia is the southernmost Austrian State.

place_196.name: Styria
place_196.description: Styria is a state in the south-east of Austria.

place_197.name: Salzburg
place_197.description: Salzburg is an Austrian city on the border of Germany, with views of the Eastern Alps.

place_199.name: The Colosseum
place_199.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

place_200.name: Dead Sea
place_200.description: The Dead Sea is a salt lake in the Jordan Rift Valley.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_205.name: Fiumicino
place_205.description: Fiumicino is a town within the City of Rome.

place_207.name: Manziana
place_207.description: Manziana is a municiplaity located to the north west of Rome.

place_897.name: France
place_897.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

place_1080.name: Florence
place_1080.description: The capital city of the Italian region of Tuscany.

place_528.name: Solfatara Caldera
place_528.description: Solfatara di Pozzuoli is a volcanic crater near Naples. Though a dormant volcano, it emits jets of steam and sulphurous fumes.

place_170.name: Malagrotta
place_170.description: Malagrotta is a nature reserve in the region of Rome, Italy.

place_214.name: Sava River
place_214.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

place_216.name: Ljubljana
place_216.description: Also known as Laybach or Laibach. Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.

place_217.name: River Danube
place_217.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

place_093.name: Skerries
place_093.description: The Skerries are a group of islands off the Antrim coast of Northern Ireland, near Portrush.

place_1191.name: Mediterranean Sea
place_1191.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

place_1142.name: Tyrrhenian Sea
place_1142.description: Part of the Mediterranean Sea off the western coast of Italy.

place_1073.name: Philadelphia
place_1073.description: the most populous city in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania

place_878.name: United States
place_878.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

place_299.name: Truro
place_299.description: The county town of Cornwall, England.

place_226.name: Geneva
place_226.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

place_256.name: Wurzen Pass
place_256.description: Wurzen Pass is a mountain pass in a col of the Karawanks Mountain range between the Austrian state of Carinthia and the the Slovenian Kranjska Gora. It is named after the town of Podkoren (Wurzen).

place_229.name: Bad Aussee
place_229.description: In Styria (Bad Aussee). Bad Aussee is a town in the Austrian state of Styria located at the confluence of the three sources of the Traun River.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

place_238.name: Southern Provinces
place_238.description: The southern provinces of Austria are Tyrol, Carinthia, and Styria.

place_106.name: Lakes of Killarney
place_106.description: Three lakes (Lough Leane, Muckross Lake - also called Middle Lake, and Upper Lake) surrounded by the MacGillycuddy's Reeks and now part of Killarney National Park.

place_237.name: Iceland
place_237.description: A Nordic island country between the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.

place_239.name: Badulla
place_239.description: Badulla is the capital city of Uva Province in the lower central hills of Sri Lanka.

place_240.name: Kandy
place_240.description: Kandy is a city in the Central Province of Sri Lanka.

place_242.name: River Aw
place_242.description: The River Awe is a short river in the south-west Highlands of Scotland.

place_243.name: Carrara
place_243.description: Carrara is a city in central Italy.

place_244.name: Mount Cenis
place_244.description: Mont Cenis is a massif in the French Alps.

place_245.name: Ravenna
place_245.description: Ravenna is a city in the north-east of Italy, near the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

place_122.name: Wales
place_122.description: Wales is a country in southwest Great Britain known for its rugged coastline, mountainous national parks, distinctive Welsh language and Celtic culture.

place_530.name: Apennines
place_530.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

place_650.name: Donauwörth
place_650.description: Donauworth is a town in Bavaria, Germany, located where the Danube and Wornitz Rivers meet.

place_251.name: Wornitz River
place_251.description: Wornitz River runs through Bavaria and is a tributary of the Danube.

place_252.name: Blenheim
place_252.description: Blenheim is the English name for the village of Blindheim in Bavaria, Germany. It is the site of the Battle of Blenheim fought in 1704.

place_688.name: Regensburg
place_688.description: Also known as Ratisbon. Regensberg is a city in Bavaria at the confluence of the Danube, Naab, and Regen rivers.

place_558.name: Lake Bohinj
place_558.description: Lake Bohinj is the largest permanent lake in Slovenia.

place_920.name: Lake Bled
place_920.description: a lake in the Julian Alps of the Upper Carniolan region of northwestern Slovenia, where it adjoins the town of Bled. Davy refers to it by the old German name of Feldes.

place_257.name: Gmunden
place_257.description: Gmunden is a town in Upper Austria, frequented as a health and summer resort.

place_260.name: Drava River
place_260.description: The Drava is a river in central southern Europe and is the fifth longest tributary of the Danube.

place_259.name: Hallstätter See
place_259.description: Hallstatter is a lake in Austria named after the small town on its shore.

place_262.name: Maribor
place_262.description: Marburg was the German name for the city, Maribor, in Slovenia.

place_261.name: Admont
place_261.description: Admont is a town in the Austrian state of Styria.

place_263.name: Odensee
place_263.description: The Odensee is a small lake in the Styria region of Austria.

place_264.name: Grundlsee
place_264.description: Grundlsee is a municipality in Styria, Austria.

place_266.name: Rhine
place_266.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

place_265.name: Schaffenhausen
place_265.description: Schaffhausen is a town in northern Switzerland, located on the banks of the Upper Rhine.

place_267.name: Vöcklabruck
place_267.description: A town in the western part of Upper Austria, which has the River Vöckla running through it.

place_268.name: Ager River
place_268.description: The Ager River in Austria is a tributary of the Traun.

place_269.name: Kammersee
place_269.description: The Kammersee, or Attersee, is a lake in Upper Austria.

place_972.name: Traunsee
place_972.description: A lake in the Salzkammergut, Upper Austria, Austria.

place_270.name: Voecla
place_270.description: The Vockla River runs through Upper Austria and is a tributary of the Ager River.

place_789.name: Kammer
place_789.description: Kammer is a village in Schörfling am Attersee, Vöcklabruck District, Upper Austria.

place_272.name: Mondsee
place_272.description: Mondsee is a town in Upper Austria located on the shore of the lake, Mondsee.

place_271.name: Landeck
place_271.description: Landeck is a town in Tyrol, Austria, located at the confluence of the Sanna and Inn Rivers.

place_273.name: Sanna River
place_273.description: The Sanna River runs through Tyrol in Austria and is a tributary of the Inn River.

place_275.name: Bludenz
place_275.description: Bludenz is a town in western Austria.

place_277.name: Innsbruck
place_277.description: Innsbruck is the capital of the Tyrol region of Austria, built on the banks of the Inn River.

place_278.name: Nassereith
place_278.description: Nassereith is a town in Austria.

place_280.name: Sillian
place_280.description: Sillian is a town in the Austrian state of Tyrol, in the district of Lienz.

place_425.name: Puster Valley
place_425.description: One of the largest longitudinal valleys in the Alps that runs in an east-west direction between Austria and Italy.

place_281.name: Leinz
place_281.description: Lienz is a town in Tyrol, Austria, located on the banks of the Drava River.

place_336.name: Brixen
place_336.description: Brixen is a town in South Tyrol, Italy.

place_309.name: Villach
place_309.description: Villach is a city in the Austrian state of Carinthia.

place_310.name: Gail River
place_310.description: The Gail River is a tributary of the Drava River.

place_311.name: Carnian Alps
place_311.description: The Carnic Alps are a range of mountains in the Southern Limestone Alps of Austria and north-eastern Italy.

place_313.name: Isonzo
place_313.description: The Soca (Izonzo) River flows through western Slovenia and Italy into the Adriatic Sea.

place_314.name: Manhart
place_314.description: Mangart is a mountain in the Julian Alps on the border between Austria and Slovenia.

place_316.name: Reutte
place_316.description: Reutte is a town in the Austrian state of Tyrol.

place_331.name: Füssen
place_331.description: Fussen is a town in Bavaria, Germany, close to the Austrian border.

place_1240.name: Kempten
place_1240.description: a town in Allgäu, about 28 miles from Füssen

place_317.name: Salza River
place_317.description: The Salza River is an eastern tributary to the Enns River in Lower Austria.

place_333.name: Bolzano
place_333.description: Bolzano is the capital city of the province of South Tyrol in northern Italy.

place_330.name: Eisack River
place_330.description: The Eisack River flows through northern Italy and the Austrian Tyrol.

place_327.name: Brunecker Turm
place_327.description: Brunecker Turm is a mountain in South Tyrol, Italy.

place_338.name: Radovljica
place_338.description: Radovljica is a town in the Upper Carnolia region of Slovenia, located on the banks of the Sava River.

place_339.name: Loibl Pass
place_339.description: The Loibl Pass is a high mountain pass that links Slovenia with Austria.

place_343.name: Triglav
place_343.description: Also known as Terglou. Triglav is the highest mountain in Slovenia, located in the Julian Alps.

place_344.name: Sava Dolinka
place_344.description: Also known as Krainer Sava. Sava Dolinka is the headwater of the Sava River in north-western Slovenia.

place_346.name: Wolksheiner
place_346.description: Also known as Lake Bohinj. Lake Bohinj is the largest lake in Slovenia, located in the Julian Alps in Upper Carnolia.

place_345.name: Sava Bohinjka
place_345.description: Also known as Wolkein Save. Sava Bohinjka is the source of the Sava River in north-west Slovenia.

place_342.name: Ratmansdorff
place_342.description: Also known as Radovljica. Radovljica is a town in the Upper Carnolia region of Slovenia, located on the banks of the Sava River.

place_349.name: Mandal, Norway
place_349.description: Mandal is a town in Vest-Agder county, Norway, which Davy visited in 1824.

place_350.name: River Tweed
place_350.description: One of the greatest salmon rivers in the UK; it flows east across the Border region in Scotland and northern England.

place_351.name: River Teviot
place_351.description: The largest tributary of the River Tweed by catchment area and a very important river for Atlantic salmon.

place_352.name: Mandal River
place_352.description: The river Mandalselva. Mandal is a town in Vest-Agder county, Norway.

place_354.name: Kristiansand
place_354.description: A city on the sea in Norway.

place_353.name: Torridal
place_353.description: A valley in Agder County, Norway.

place_355.name: Rhone River
place_355.description: A major river in France and Switzerland.

place_356.name: Lyon
place_356.description: Lyon is the third-largest city in France. It is located at the confluence of the Rivers Rhône and Saône, to the north-west of the French Alps.

place_357.name: Arendal
place_357.description: A town or district in Agder County in south-eastern Norway.

place_358.name: Halden
place_358.description: Between 1665 and 1928, known as Fredrikshald. A town and a municipality in Viken County, Norway.

place_359.name: Oslo
place_359.description: Capital of Norway, previously named Christiania.

place_364.name: The Sarp Falls
place_364.description: Also known as the Fall(s) of Glommen. The second largest waterfalls by discharge in Europe located on Norway's longest river, the Glomma.

place_898.name: Vienna
place_898.description: Austria’s capital, lies in the country’s east on the Danube River.

place_876.name: Lapland
place_876.description: The largest and northernmost region of Finland.

place_363.name: Trollhattan Falls
place_363.description: Trollhattan Falls is a waterfall on the Gota River in Sweden.

place_625.name: Vicenza
place_625.description: Vicenza is a city in the north-east of Italy.

place_623.name: Trento
place_623.description: Trento is an Italian city located on the Adige River.

place_426.name: Adige
place_426.description: The second-longest river in Italy, which rises in the province of South Tyrol, near the Italian border with Austria and Switzerland.

place_1403.name: River Tay
place_1403.description: The River Tay is the longest river in Scotland and the seventh-longest in Great Britain.

place_624.name: Bassano del Grappa
place_624.description: Bassano del Grappa is a city in northern Vicenza region of Italy.

place_619.name: Brenta River
place_619.description: The Brenta River has its source in Trentino, north-east Italy, and flows into the Adriatic. It rises from the lakes Levico and Caldonazzo.

place_620.name: Lago di Levico
place_620.description: Lago di Levico is a lake in Trentino, north-east Italy. It is known as the 'Little Brother' of the larger nearby lake, Lago di Caldonazzo. Both lakes are the source of the Brenta River.

place_621.name: Lago di Caldonazzo
place_621.description: Lago di Cadonazzo is a lake in Trentino, north-east Italy. It lies alongside Lago di Levico. Both lakes form the source of the Brenta River.

place_622.name: Verona
place_622.description: Verona is a city located on the Adige River in the north of Italy.

place_607.name: Rovereto
place_607.description: Rovereto is a city in northern Italy located on the Adige River.

place_608.name: Valley of Rocks
place_608.description: The Valley of Rocks is a dry valley that runs parallel to the coast in north Devon, near the village of Lynton.

place_609.name: River Spey
place_609.description: The River Spey is located in north-east Scotland and is important for both salmon fishing and whisky production.

place_610.name: Brenner Pass
place_610.description: The Brenner Pass is a mountain pass through the Alps that forms the border between Austria and Italy.

place_618.name: Terracina
place_618.description: Terracina is a city in the Latina Province of Italy, south-east of Rome.

place_614.name: Civitavecchia
place_614.description: Civittavecchia is a city in the district of Rome, Italy, and is a sea port on the Tyrrhenian Sea.

place_861.name: Fiumicino
place_861.description: Fiumicino is a town and comune in the Metropolitan City of Rome, Lazio, central Italy.

place_612.name: Campagna
place_612.description: The Roman Campagna is an area of low-lying countryside surrounding Rome, where both the Tiber and Aniene Rivers flow.

place_613.name: Alban Hills
place_613.description: The Alban Hills are the caldera remains of a quiescent volcano, south-east of Rome.

place_615.name: Tiber River
place_615.description: The Tiber River is the third longest river in Italy. Rome is located on its banks.

place_616.name: Palatine Hill
place_616.description: The centremost and most important of the seven hills of Rome. It has been called the 'first nucleus of the Roman Empire'.
